In Julia, Write a function `clean_column` that cleans a column name (`col`) by lowercasing it, stripping any leading or trailing whitespaces, and replacing any spaces and hyphens with an underscore, eg, "My Column" becomes "my_column".

In Julia, you can define a function to clean column names as follows:

```julia
function clean_column(col::String)
    # Lowercase the string
    col = lowercase(col)
    
    # Strip leading and trailing whitespace
    col = strip(col)
    
    # Replace spaces and hyphens with underscore
    col = replace(col, r"\s|-" => "_")
    
    return col
end
```

This function `clean_column` takes a string `col` as input, and returns a cleaned version of the column name. It first lowercases the string, then strips any leading or trailing whitespace, and finally replaces all spaces and hyphens with an underscore.

You can call this function on any string to clean the column name:

```julia
julia> clean_column("My Column")
"my_column"

julia> clean_column("my-column")
"my_column"

julia> clean_column(" My Column ")
"my_column"
```

This function is general enough to work with any string, not just column names. If you want to ensure that the input is a valid column name (e.g., it doesn't contain non-alphanumeric characters other than hyphens and underscores), you would need additional checks in your function.
